definitions.definition: to lose blood, especially from a wound or an injury

examples.text: He was bleeding from a gash on his head.
The small blood vessels in the nose bleed easily.

definitions.definition: (in the past) to take blood from somebody as a way of treating disease
to force somebody to pay a lot of money over a period of time

examples.text: The company seems intent on bleeding us for every penny we have.

definitions.definition: to remove air or liquid from something so that it works correctly
to spread from one area of something to another area

examples.text: Keep the paint fairly dry so that the colours don't bleed into each other.

definitions.definition: to take away all somebody’s money

examples.text: The big corporations are bleeding some of these small countries dry.

definitions.definition: used to say that you do not feel sympathy for somebody

examples.text: ‘I have to go to Brazil on business.’ ‘My heart bleeds for you!’

wordOrigin: Old English blēdan, of Germanic origin; related to blood.
